results.title: Trucks in our neighbourhood: a first film
results.creator_credit: BFA Educational Media, Film Associates, Dan McCarroll and Frank Stokes
results.brief_description:
Shows the various trucks that might come to the neighbourhood. Also shows the workers who drive them as they provide services, make deliveries and repairs and do the general work needed to keep a neighbourhood running smoothly.
Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Truckers
results.creator_credit: Cosgrove-Hall Productions, Jackie Cockle, Chris Taylor and Francis Vose
results.brief_description: This is a story of Nomes. Nomes are four inches high and they crashed to Earth 15,000 years ago. To them, a year lasts as long as ten human years, so in their eyes, humans move in slow motion, their voices booming like the mooing of monster cows. As generations of Nomes come and go, the countryside in which they settle becomes full of dangerous motorways where the Nomes are forced to scavenge in bins for food. Fearing extinction, ten Nomes, led by newcomer Masklin, escape in the back of a lorry, taking with them a mysterios black box called “The Thing.” Based on the very successful novel by author Terry Pratchett.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cosgrove-Hall Productions, Jackie Cockle, Chris Taylor and Francis Vose

results.title: Trout that stole the rainbow
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Dennis Sawyer and Eva Szasz
results.brief_description: In this original fable the world loses its colours when a trout, obsessed by the beauty of the rainbow, steals it from the sky. As punishment, the sun paints the trout in rainbow colours that can be enjoyed by all, but the trout himself.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ONF | NFB, Dennis Sawyer and Eva Szasz

results.title: Trout stream
results.brief_description: From the rocky bottom of a stream this film brings you a remarkable study of the eastern brook trout, showing how instinct protects a fish and lets it survive, and how the same instinct holds it prisoner of its environment. Photographed in color at natural speed, the film’s most remarkable sequence shows the spawning of fish, the event of regeneration as eggs are laid and fertilized, then hatch.

results.title: Trout in the Karri Country
results.creator_credit: Western Australian Government Film Unit and Norman A. Uren
results.brief_description: Shows the pleasures of trout fishing in the forest streams of south-west Western Australia. Also shows the whole process of breeding from the stripping of ova from the female, the milking of the male, the growth of the ova, the hatching and growth of the fingerlings and the final release of the young fish into farm dams and streams.

results.title: Trout in New Zealand
results.brief_description: Describes the work of the Government hatcheries in keeping rivers and streams in New Zealand well stocked with trout and salmon. The film shows how trout are caught and stripped and how fry are released in streams when hatched.

results.title: Trout country
results.brief_description: Trout fishing in the rivers and lakes of Tasmania. Shows the breeding grounds and the work of the Inland Fisheries Commission in studying the habits of the trout. Explains the five ways to angle trout - dry fly casting, wet fly fishing, spinning, natural bait from boat or shore, and trawling from a boat. Shows the famous Shannon Rise.

results.title: Troubled minds: the lithium revolution [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Omar Khayam Films, John Lewis and Dennis K. Smith
results.brief_description: Another first for Australian medical science is revealed in this fascinating documentary about Dr John Cade. Cade was a POW in Changi during World War II and during his time there he made the link between mental illness and body chemistry. At the time there were no other treatments for the mentally ill other than shock treatment, lobotomy and institutionalisation. With his wife and two young sons (who grew up in the grounds of a hospital), Cade’s research done whilst a doctor in residence, paved the way for the current treatment of bi-polar disorder and for chemical treatment of the mentally ill. The naturally occurring salt ‘lithium’ he worked with meant that the pharmaceutical companies were initially resistant to embrace his findings but those who followed up on his initial research and doctors who pursued the use of the salts, have resulted the de-institutionalisation of many people the world over and a revolution in the treatment of the mentally ill. A mixture of re-creations of the era, original historical footage and of contemporary interviews, this film serves as an interesting historical account as well as an educational resource. A Film Australia National Interest Program, developed with the assistance of Film Victoria and produced in association with SBS Independent.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Film Australia, Omar Khayam Films, John Lewis and Dennis K. Smith
